note_models.name: Cloze

fields:
Clinical symptoms of oesophagitis include:
1. {{c1::Dysphagia}} - difficulty swallowing
2. {{c1::Heartburn}} - episodic substernal pain
3. {{c1::Odynophagia}} - painful swallowing

Clinical symptoms of oesophagitis can overlap with these different conditions:
1. {{c1::Chest}} pain
2. Functional {{c1::dyspepsia}}
3. {{c1::Pericarditis}} - inflammation

{{c1::Heartburn}} is episodic substernal pain, worse after meals and on reclining and relieved, temporarily by antacids. Can be accompanied by complaints of a bitter taste in the mouth (regurgitation) or a welling up in the mouth of a salty tasting (salivary derived) fluid.
Substernal pain relieved by antacids and recurs at least once per week over an extended period - diagnosis of {{c1::GERD}}

Odynophagia - painful swallowing, acute and severe form of esophagitis, typically with mucosal {{c1::ulceration}}.
Experienced substernally as an aching or stabbing pain aggravated by the act of swallowing, even swallowing saliva.
Common in oesophagitis caused by infeciton, pills and radiation, but rare in oesophagitis caused by {{c1::reflux}}.

Investigative procedures that are useful in diagnosing oesophagitis include an upper {{c1::endoscopy.}}
It is very sensitive (90%) and specific, provides direct {{c1::visualization}}, and can perform therapeutic interventions.

Lacerations in oesophagitis are mainly {{c1::longitudinal}} tears near the gastroesophageal junction, and is mostly associated with alcoholic binges. It happens most likely due to {{c1::mechanical}} trauma in conjunction with failure of gastroesophageal muscular relaxation. Mucosal defect of varying ranges, {{c1::supportive}} therapy usually given.
Complications include mild/moderate haemorrhage, however it rarely ruptures (Boerhaave syndrome).

{{c1::Chemical}} oesophagitis:
Stratified squamous mucosa damage by alcohol, corrosive acids or alkalis, heavy smoking, hot fluids.
{{c1::Pill}}-induced oesophagitis can also occur.

Infectious oesophagitis:
Most commonly seen in {{c1::immunocompromised}} patients
1. Candia
2. Herpes Simplex
3. CMV

Eosinophilic oesophagitis is an {{c1::immunologically}} mediated entity (food allergy). Histologically characterized by large numbers of {{c1::intraepithelial}} eosinophils. 
Acid {{c1::reflux}} is not a prominent cause, PPIs do not provide relief. Can manifest as chest pain or heartburn, solid food {{c1::dysphagia}} and food impaction are characteristic, feeding intolerance or GERD like symptoms in children.
Longitudinal {{c1::furrows}} can be seen in eosinophilic oesophagitis, and reflux oesophagitis as well. Whitish {{c1::plaque}} and {{c1::circular}} rings are also diagnostics.

Histological features of eosinophilic oesophagitis include:
1. {{c1::Dilated}} intercellular spaces
2. {{c1::Intraepithelial}} eosinophils
3. Basal layer {{c1::hyperplasia}}

Treatment of eosinophilic oesophagitis include:
- Removal of {{c1::allergic}} source (PPI may be of limited use)
- {{c1::Topical}} steroids such as fluticasone and budesonide
- May require {{c1::dilation}} treatments if there are stricturers

GERD oesophagitis: condition in which the gastric or {{c1::duodenal}} contents leak backwards from the stomach into the oesophagus. LES muscles do not close properly. 
Long term consequences include:
1. Bleeding (almost never massive)
2. {{c1::Stricture}} (abnormal tightening)
3. {{c1::Barrett's}} esophagus with possible {{c1::barrett}} ulcer

Risk factors for GERD include:
Hiatal {{c1::hernia}}
Pregnancy
Scleroderma
Obesity
Cigarettes
Alcohol
Certain medicines
{{c1::Inversely}} associated with H.pylori infection

Pathophysiology of GERD:
A. {{c1::Abnormal}} lower esophageal sphincter
- functional (frequent transient LES relaxation)
- mechanical (hypotensive LES)
- foods (coffee, alcohol)
- medications (CCBs)
- location (hiatal hernia)

or

B. Increased {{c1::abdominal}} pressure

Diagnostic evaluations of GERD include:
1. Upper {{c1::endoscopy}}
2. Esophageal {{c1::biopsy}} - basal cell hyperplasia, oedema or inflammatory findings
3. pH monitoring by pH probe
Preffered method for establishing GERD as cause of symptoms:
Empirical trial of acid suppression with {{c1::PPI}} - normalizes acidity in 95% of subjects

Histology of GERD:
1. {{c1::Elongation}} of lamina propria
2. Basal cell {{c1::hyperplasia}}
3. Presence of lymphocytes, eosinophils (not as many as eosinophilic esophagitis), neutrophils

Complications of GERD include:
1. {{c1::Erosive}} esophagitis (responsible for 40-60% of GERD symptoms)
 - severity of symptoms fail to match severity of {{c1::erosive}} esophagitis
2. Esophageal {{c1::stricture}}
 - result of healing of {{c1::erosive}} esophagitis
 - may need dilation

Most dangerous complication of GERD is {{c1::Barrett's}} esophagus. 
- intestinal {{c1::metaplasia}} of the esophagus
- associated with the development of {{c1::adenocarcinoma}}
- salmon pink transition (indicator)
- complete replacement of {{c1::squamous}} to intestinal matter

´Acid damages lining of esophagus and causes chronic oesophagitis
´Damaged area heals in a metaplastic process and abnormal columnar cells replace squamous cells
´This specialized intestinal metaplasia can progress to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma

Histology of barrett's esophagus:
{{c1::Goblet}} cells - accumulation of cytoplasmic intestinal-type mucin
Universal presence of {{c1::chronic}} inflammation
Surface glandular epithelium with tall columnar cells

Low grade dysplasia in barrett's esophagus:
Nuclear {{c1::enlargement}}
Nuclear hyperchromasia
Nuclear contour {{c1::irregularity}}

High grade dysplasia:
Enlarged {{c1::hyperchromatic}} nuclei with little {{c1::cytoplasm}} in cells
Surface involvement required to distinguish from low grade

GERD treatment:
{{c1::Relieve}} symptoms and prevent relapse and complications
Lifestyle modications
{{c1::Antacids}} or {{c1::antacid}}/alginate combination - H2 blockers, PPI
